content:
Hi,
why is max-width 1400px for desktop and web client? How can I make it larger? There is too much free space..
@Alex Ivanov because studies consistently show that reading content is a lot faster if content isn't super wide.
This is why modern blog software designs always have a maximum width for text similar to what Zulip uses.
But why is it hardcoded? I would like to change it with custom CSS in desktop client. Is it possible?
yeah, you can inject custom CSS into the desktop client
Yes I can. But, as I found out, 1400px is a hardcoded value. Custom CSS doesn't work. Is there a way to change this somehow?

Out of interest, is there a reason not to use a width in em rather than px, if it is based on 'reading', ie. font size? That said, I know that increasing the page scale in the browser 'just works' as it is, but it would be useful to know :)
I think going consistently with px is the best policy. Browsers seem to handle px pretty well with zoom.
I am not a big fan of making fonts relative to each other. It makes it impossible to make local improvements without unintended consequences.
In the webapp literally every important resize calculation is pixel based. So staying in pixel space is prudent and simple.

Apparently rem is a lot bette than em but personally I agree with Steve. I don’t have much experience with relative fonts but I do feel they’re complicated to understand and don’t really make life a whole lot easier for developers.
@Boris Yankov Why do you prefer relative fonts to pixels? You gave :thumbs_down: to my post about pixels.

@Alex Ivanov For me, injecting the following works:

.app-main, .header-main, #compose-container {
  max-width: none !important;
}

Would it be possible to have that as a default/switch in the desktop app? It feels more like an app that way, and if people don't want it that large they can simply resize the window. I understand why it's the case in the browser and agree with the decision. But it should be full width in the Desktop App imho.
@Steve Howell since you said you will take a break from CSS today, I think this is the best time to overwhelm you with some of it.
I am not a big fan of making fonts relative to each other. It makes it impossible to make local improvements without unintended consequences.
@Jakob Thank you very much. It works
